original: Erlandson, Karl Simon, rektor, Nässjö, f. 19/5/89 i Tjärstad, Ö.ster-götl. 1., av Per Magnus E. o. Elisa Sofia Dahlström. G. 18 m. Helfrid Anderson. Barn: Hel frid f. 19, Hervor 21, g. m. aman. Hans Landelius, Sithlm. — Stud lex. i Linköp. 09, fil. kand. i Upps. 13, fil. mag. 14, licistud. i hiist., provår i Upps. 23. Vik. adj. i Öister-sund 16-18, lär. v. Upps. ensk. lärov. o. privrgymn. 18-23, vik. lektor v. Upps. folksk:sem. 24, v. Upps, ensk. lärov. 24-25, ord. ämneslär. v. Norrköp. komm. mel lans k. 25, adj. i mo-dersm., tyska o. hiist. m. samh :lära v. norra latin i Sthilm sed. 27, rektor f. Nässjö samreafek. sed. 40, fd. timlär. v. navigisk., Whitlockska o. Waliinska ’sk. samt borgarsk. o. polissk. i Sthlm. Bitr. hist isakk. bl. 31 års isfcolisakik., ’sakk. i 37 års komm. betr. begynn :-språket i realsk., medi. av granskn:nd f. priv. skriftl. prov i moderism., bitr. i stat. ilärob :nd f. lärob. i modersm., bitr. i 40 års iskoiutredn. I Näsisjö bl. a. led. av stadsfullm. o. dess be-redn :utsk., ordf. i styr. f. högerfören., yrkessk., orkesterfören., tenniskl., iuftsk :fören.. Norra Smål. iokalavd. av Histilär. riksorg., v. ordf. i lokal-avd. av Riksfören. f. svenskh. bevar. i uti., ordf. i nykterh:ndn, sekr. i lo-kalavd. av Skidfrämj., styr :led. i lokal avd. av för en. Norden. Östg. nations i Upps. andre kur. 15-16, förste kur. 16. Ansv. utg. av isamt red. f. Tidn. f. Sv:es lärov. 33-38. Re.s. t. Tyskl. 20, 27 o. 28, Finl. 32, Tyskl., Frankr. o. Belg. 37, Tyskl. o. Ung. 39. Skr.: Omarb. allm. hrst. f. realsk. (tilliSL m. G. Jacob-son), Tyska arbiets-blad f. realisk. _I-II (del I tills. m. H. Gerring), De första grunderna i språk 0. ’Stil f. realsk. (tills. m. E. Vendel-felt), art. o. rec. i tidn. o. tidskr. RVO.
translated: Erlandson, Karl Simon, principal, Nässjö, born May 19, 1889 in Tjärstad, Östergötland, son of Per Magnus E. and Elisa Sofia Dahlström. Married Helfrid Anderson in 1918. Children: Helfrid (born 1919), Hervor (born 1921, married to aman. Hans Landelius, from Söderhamn). Studied law in Linköping in 1909, received a Bachelor of Arts degree from Uppsala University in 1913, a Master of Arts degree in 1914, and completed a licentiate degree in history with a teaching certificate after a probationary year in Uppsala in 1923. Held various teaching positions, including substitute teacher in Östersund from 1916 to 1918, teacher at Uppsala private high school and gymnasium from 1918 to 1923, substitute teacher at Uppsala people's seminary in 1924, teacher at Uppsala private high school from 1924 to 1925, subject teacher in Norrköping municipal school from 1925, and language teacher in German, history, and social studies at Norra Latin school in Stockholm from 1927. Became principal of Nässjö samrealskola in 1940. Formerly working as a teacher of navigation, at Whitlockskolan and Wallinska school, as well as at Stockholm's burgess and police schools. Participated in historical research from 1931, and a consultant for 37 years on the subject of the beginning of language in real school. Participated in state policy, working on developing language instruction as well as contributing to a 40-year school survey in Nässjö, serving as a member of the city council and its committee, chairman of the board of right-wing association, vocational school, orchestra association, tennis club, local division of the National Association for the Protection of Swedish Heritage Abroad, vice chairman of the local division of the National Temperance Society, secretary of the local division of the Ski Promotion Association, member of the board for the Association for the Nordic Countries, and the East Gotlandic Nation in Uppsala. Responsible for editing and publishing the journal Tidn. f. Sv:es lärov. from 1933 to 1938. Traveled to Germany in 1920, 1927, and 1928, Finland in 1932, Germany, France, and Belgium in 1937, and Germany and Hungary in 1939. Wrote books, including Overhauled General History for Real School, German labor journal for Real School I-II, The First Foundations of Language and Style for Real School (with E. Vendelfelt), and articles and reviews in newspapers and magazines. Member of The Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences.
